Award.AwardTitle: Assessing the effect of dissolution on key Pliocene Mg/Ca-based tropical temperature records
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tropical Pacific harbors the largest mass of very warm water of the world's ocean and is a primary source of heat and moisture to the atmosphere. Changes in the temperature gradients across the tropical Pacific drive major changes in tropical circulation and global climate. Studies of the tropical Pacific during the Pliocene Epoch (three to five million years before present) can provide important insight into how the Earth's climate behaved at a time in the geologic past when atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations were similar to today (~100 ppm higher than preindustrial values). Reconstructions of Pliocene tropical Pacific temperatures using geochemical techniques agree with some Pliocene climate model simulations, but not others. This unresolved issue is the focus of this research project. The aim of this project is to re-evaluate the Pliocene temperature estimates that are based on the magnesium to calcium ratio (Mg/Ca) of fossil shells by quantifying whether changes in the preservation of the shells resulted in biased temperature estimates. The results of this work willl provide important validation of climate models used to simulate warm climate states. This project involves the professional training of a graduate student, training of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields, and outreach to undergraduates in the San Francisco and Monterey Bay Areas.

Many of the existing sea surface temperature records from the tropical Pacific are derived from the Mg/Ca composition of planktonic foraminifera, which is susceptible to dissolution on the seafloor and in the sediments; enhanced dissolution results in a cold temperature bias. It is standard practice to correct for the effect of dissolution using carbonate ion concentrations at the location and water depth of the sediment core. However, dissolution can change with time and the effects of changing dissolution on Mg/Ca-based temperature estimates is the most likely source of proxy bias in the tropical Pacific. This project will measure the boron to calcium (B/Ca) ratio of benthic foraminifera in the same samples that were used to produce published Mg/Ca-temperature estimates in the tropical Pacific over the last 5 Myrs. B/Ca is a proxy for carbonate ion concentration, and thus can be used to properly adjust the Mg/Ca-temperature estimates to account for dissolution. The new B/Ca analyses will be applied to evaluating potential dissolution biases at Ocean Drilling Project (ODP) Hole 806 in the West Pacific warm pool, but will also, using a more limited set of analyses, evaluate ODP 847 in the East Pacific cold tongue. Both the absolute temperatures and the West-East temperature difference will be quantified once the effect of dissolution is taken into account, and compared to climate model simulations of the Pliocene warm period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The early Pliocene (3-5 Ma) was 3-4C warmer globally, but pCO2 was only slightly higher, than preindustrial values. Two key observations of the Pliocene tropics are currently debated: 1) sea-surface temperatures (SSTs) in the West Pacific Warm Pool (WPWP) that were similar to preindustrial conditions, and 2) a significantly lower zonal SST gradient between the WPWP and the Eastern Equatorial Pacific (EEP), referred to as permanent El Nino-like conditions. On one hand, these observations are difficult to reconcile with our theoretical understanding of the response of tropical SSTs to greenhouse gas forcing. On the other hand, though unexpected, these observations are consistent with sub-surface ocean and higher latitude climate patterns and could indicate that changes in cloud albedo and/or ocean mixing played a larger role in Pliocene global warmth than predicted by models forced with elevated greenhouse gases. Much of the debate hinges on the accuracy of Mg/Ca-based SST records from planktonic foraminifera; the WPWP record shows little long-term SST change, while the EEP record shows much warmer Pliocene SSTs, yielding a lower east-west difference. However, previously published TEX86 SST data indicate a cooling trend since the Pliocene that differs markedly from Mg/Ca-temperature records in the West Pacific. These discrepancies have engendered doubt in the scientific community as to the accuracy of pre-Pleistocene Mg/Ca temperature records. Though much of the debate has focused on changes in seawater Mg/Ca, post-depositional dissolution is the most likely source of bias in the Mg/Ca-SST records. Thus, this study is aimed at determining whether existing Mg/Ca SST records at WPWP site 806 are biased by changes in dissolution, and if so, produce a new dissolution-corrected Mg/Ca SST record. To do this, we collected benthic foraminiferal B/Ca data at WEP site 806, to constrain possible changes in corrosiveness of the bottom waters that could have affected Mg/Ca-based SST estimates. We found that there was no significant change in bottom water corrosiveness and therefore that dissolution did not affect Mg/Ca-based estimates over the last 5 myrs. This implies that 1) SSTs in the WPWP was similar to preindustrial conditions despite higher pCO2, and 2) there was a robust permanent El Nino-like mean state in the tropical Pacific.

 

Intellectual Merit: Some global climate models have difficulty producing the temperature patterns shown in Pliocene Mg/Ca data, particularly in the WPWP, creating disagreement over which reconstructions (model or data) are correct. This points to future work to further investigate possible model biases, and possible additional biases in the paleoceanographic data. This work is critical because the WPWP is a critical region for calculating climate sensitivity, targeting Pliocene WPWP SSTs will enable more accurate simulation of future climate under anthropogenic warming. In addition, our proposed study represents the first attempt to correct for time-varying dissolution in a Mg/Ca record; given the large impact of dissolution on calculated Mg/Ca temperatures, this approach should be encouraged. Broader Impacts : Our proposal has three parts: 1) professional training of GSR Sarah White, who took the lead writing this proposal and conducting the research; 2) training of undergraduate students; and 3) outreach to middle school and undergraduates in the San Francisco and Monterey Bay Areas, via a teaching module designed and presented by Sarah White.
